column4: Fact check: Palmer United Party Senator Jacqui Lambie incorrect on defence spending
column5: Is Australia's defence spending as a ratio of GDP the lowest it has been since pre-World War II?

column4: Fact check: Labor blocking $5 billion of its own savings measures
column5: Finance Minister Mathias Cormann claims Labor is opposing $5 billion in savings that it initiated when it was in government.

column4: Fact check: Will Australian universities 'slide into mediocrity' without reform?
column5: Education Minister Christopher Pyne claims that without deregulation Australia's universities will slide into mediocrity and be overtaken by Asian competitors.

column4: Fact check: Who has a say in sending Australian troops to war?
column5: Foreign Minister Julie Bishop claims the government of the day has the ultimate responsibility for making decisions involving Australia's military.

column4: Fact check: Do young, childless women earn more than men?
column5: American academic and commentator Kay Hymowitz claims childless women in their twenties in the US earn more than men.

column4: Fact check: Tony Abbott incorrect on impact of superannuation changes on workers
column5: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims delaying a mandated increase to compulsory superannuation contributions will not leave employees worse off.

column4: Fact check: Will 50pc of Australians die before they can access their superannuation?
column5: Palmer United Party leader Clive Palmer claims it is a "statistical fact" that more than 50 per cent of Australians will be dead by the time they get access to their super.

column4: Fact check: Have 100,000 new jobs been created this year?
column5: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims more than 100,000 new jobs were created in his first year in office.

column4: Fact check: Health Minister Peter Dutton's dementia facts flawed
column5: Health Minister Peter Dutton claims the number of people diagnosed with dementia will soar to 7,500 a week "in a number of years" from 170 per week today.

column4: Fact check: Tony Abbott exaggerating India's 'absolutely impeccable record' on nuclear non-proliferation
column5: As the government formalises an agreement to sell uranium to India, over-turning a decades-old ban, Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims the Asian nation has an "absolutely impeccable record" on nuclear non-proliferation.

column4: It's war, not 'a mission': Abbott incorrect on Iraq action
column5: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims Australian use of air strikes and Australian special forces to fight Islamic state militants in Iraq amounts to "a mission" rather than "a war".

column4: Fact check: Journalists face 10 years' jail for exposing security agency bungles
column5: Labor frontbencher Anthony Albanese claims the Government's new terror laws mean members of the media face potential penalties of five to 10 years' jail for exposing what might be an error made by security agencies.

column4: Fact check: Science, research and innovation spending cut to 'historic low'
column5: Greens deputy leader Adam Bandt claims the Federal Government has cut spending on science, research and innovation to a "historic low".

column4: Fact check: Does a farmer die by suicide every four days in Australia as Bob Katter says?
column5: Federal MPmBob Katter claims a farmer commits suicide every four days in Australia.

column4: Fact check: Was Hong Kong ever promised democracy?
column5: Martin Lee, a lawyer who helped draft Hong Kong's constitution, claims the people of Hong Kong were promised democracy.

column4: Fact check: Health Minister Peter Dutton misleading on Red Cross Ebola funding
column5: Health Minister Peter Dutton claims the Federal Government provided $18 million to non-government organisations such as the Red Cross to fight Ebola in Africa.

column4: Fact check: Is workplace discrimination against older people costing $10 billion a year?
column5: Age Discrimination Commissioner Susan Ryan claims Australia is losing about $10 billion a year by failing to employ more people over the age of 55.

column4: Fact check: Are de facto relationships more unstable than marriages?
column5: Social Services Minister Kevin Andrews claims data shows that de facto relationships have a higher incidence of break-up than marriages.

column4: Fact File: Backing the Melbourne Cup favourite: Are the odds in your favour?
column5: How often does the favourite actually win? And would you be ahead or behind if you bet on the favourite every year?

column4: Fact check: How much will the fuel tax hike leave you out of pocket?
column5: The Abbott government claims an increase in the fuel excise will cost households an extra 40 cents a week. But the Australian Automobile Association says the Government is being disengenuous because the average motorist will actually pay about $140 extra a year.

column4: Fact check: Are feral cats killing over 20 billion native animals a year?
column5: Environment Minister Greg Hunt claims up to 20 million feral cats are each killing four native Australian animals a night, destroying over 20 billion animals a year.

column4: Fact check: Are Victorians waiting longer than ever for ambulances to arrive?
column5: Victorian Opposition Leader Daniel Andrews claims ambulance service has never been worse, with response times longer than ever before.

column4: Fact check: Did Joh Bjelke-Petersen instigate the Fitzgerald inquiry?
column5: Barnaby Joyce claims Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen brought about the Fitzgerald inquiry.

column4: Fact check: Hockey overstates the power of congress to block Obama's emissions pledge
column5: Treasurer Joe Hockey claims it will be difficult for US president Barack Obama to deliver on climate change pledges because he must first get past a hostile US congress.

column4: Fact check: Do Australia, US 'compare favourably' on emissions targets?
column5: Environment Minister Greg Hunt claims Australia's emissions reduction efforts can be compared favourably to the United States.

column4: Fact check: Does the gap between rich and poor affect a country's growth?
column5: Opposition foreign affairs spokeswoman Tanya Plibersek claims OECD data shows that the larger the difference between rich and poor countries, the less likely a nation's growth will be strong.

column4: Fact check: Has train punctuality improved under the Napthine Government?
column5: Victorian Premier Denis Napthine claims his Government has "improved train punctuality".

column4: Fact check: Has the Abbott Government 'dropped the ball' on unemployment?
column5: Opposition Leader Bill Shorten claims unemployment stood at 5.7 per cent when the Abbott government came to office in September 2013, but it rose to 6.2 per cent by December 2014.

column4: Fact check: Campbell Newman exaggerating crime statistics ahead of Qld poll
column5: Queensland Premier Campbell Newman claims Queensland crime rates have "gone down very very significantly" because of Liberal policy.

column4: Fact check: Labor claims unemployment in Qld highest in 11 years
column5: Queensland Opposition Leader Annastacia Palaszczuk claims there are almost 31,000 more Queenslanders without a job since March 2012 and blames the Liberal government for the rise.

column4: Fact check: Did jobs growth triple in 2014, as Tony Abbott says?
column5: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims Australia's "jobs growth in 2014 was triple the rate in 2013 – with 4,000 new jobs a week."

column4: Fact check: Joe Hockey's claim that people work half the year to pay income tax incorrect
column5: Treasurer Joe Hockey claims Australian income tax rates are a disincentive to earn. But how much income tax do Australians pay?

column4: Fact check: Triggs correct on the length of time children spent in detention
column5: Australian Human Rights Commission president Gillian Triggs claims that in the first months of the Coalition Government, the time children spent in immigration detention "was reaching quite exceptional levels"

column4: Fact check: Hockey over-eggs 'borrowing $100 million a day' claim
column5: Treasurer Joe Hockey has warned that Australia is at a tipping point and living beyond its means.

column4: Fact check: No proof the death penalty prevents crime
column5: Victorian Supreme Court judge Lex Lasry claims the death penalty does not deter crime, "it's just a terrible thing to do".

column4: Fact check: Did the Government inherit the 'worst set of accounts' in history?
column5: Deputy Liberal Leader Julie Bishop claims the Abbott Government inherited the worst set of financial accounts in Australia's history.

column4: Fact check: Did the Abbott Government cut $1 billion from child care?
column5: Opposition Leader Bill Shorten claims the Federal Government has cut $1 billion from childcare.

column4: Fact check: Did NSW Labor fail to deliver 'a single railway line'?
column5: NSW Premier Mike Baird claims Labor did not deliver a single railway line when in government.

column4: Fact check: Is crime in NSW the lowest it's been in 25 years?
column5: Putting law and order policy at the forefront of his re-election campaign, NSW Premier Mike Baird claims crime in the state is at its lowest level in decades.

column4: Fact check: Does the minimum wage increase unemployment?
column5: Opposition Leader Bill Shorten claims the evidence from Europe shows the minimum wage doesn't contribute to unemployment levels.

column4: Fact check: Did the Coalition Government cut $3b from the NSW health budget?
column5: NSW Opposition Leader Luke Foley claims the Coalition Government has cut $3 billion from health.

column4: Fact check: Does privatisation increase electricity bills?
column5: NSW Opposition Leader Luke Foley claims electricity privatisation pushes up power prices and households in privatised South Australia have the highest bills.

column4: Fact check: Banning dumping of dredge spoil on the Great Barrier Reef
column5: A recent move by the Federal Government to ban the disposal of dredge spoil near the Great Barrier Reef has been met with scepticism by environmental campaigners concerned for the health of the reef.

column4: Fact check: Are 80,000 Victorians using ice?
column5: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews claims about 80,000 Victorians used the drug ice in 2014.

column4: NSW election: Get the facts behind the claims
column5: During the New South Wales election campaign both major parties have made claims in key policy battlegrounds. But how much of what the leaders claim checks out?

column4: Fact check: Do the states and territories need to agree to change the GST?
column5: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims the Government cannot change the GST without the agreement of the states and territories, and consensus in the federal parliament.

column4: Fact check: Are superannuation tax breaks fair, or do they favour the rich?
column5: Shadow treasurer Chris Bowen claims the top 10 per cent of income earners get more than 30 per cent of tax concessions in superannuation.

column4: Fact check: Does halal certification fund terrorism?
column5: One Nation founder Pauline Hanson claims that halal certification is a $3 trillion industry that funds Islamic organisations and terrorism.

column4: Fact check: Did abolishing negative gearing push up rents?
column5: Treasurer Joe Hockey claims abolishing negative gearing could push up rents, because that's what happened in the 1980s.

column4: Fact check: How much is subsidising cheap paracetamol costing the government?
column5: Health Minister Sussan Ley claims subsidising paracetamol that can be bought cheaply without a prescription is costing the government $73 million a year.

column4: Promise tracker: Where does the Government stand ahead of the 2015 budget?
column5: ABC Fact Check is tracking the Coalition's pre-election commitments. See which promises the Government has kept which ones it has broken.

column4: Fact check: The Coalition's stance on paid parental leave 'double dipping'
column5: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims the Coalition announced plans to stop new mothers "double dipping" on paid parental leave before the 2013 election.

column4: Fact check: Andrew Forrest exaggerating big miner influence over iron ore
column5: Fortescue Metals Group chairman Andrew Forrest claims Australia is the world's biggest iron ore producer and has more control of iron ore than OPEC ever had of oil.

column4: Fact check: Where do Australians get illegal guns?
column5: Nationals Senator Bridget McKenzie claims most guns used in crime are illegally imported rather than coming from licensed owners.

column4: Fact check: Tony Abbott's claim Labor spent like 'drunken sailors' in office is spin
column5: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims growth in spending is lower under the Coalition than it was under Labor.

column4: Fact check: How does Australia's plan to strip foreign fighters of citizenship compare to other nations?
column5: Defending proposed changes to give him the power to strip Australian citizenship from dual nationals fighting with terrorist groups, Immigration Minister Peter Dutton claims Australia is not "ahead of the pack" as countries such as the UK, US, New Zealand and France  have similar laws.

column4: Fact check: How can the GST on tampons be scrapped?
column5: Treasurer Joe Hockey and Prime Minister Tony Abbott claim they need the agreement of the states and territories to remove the GST from tampons and pads.

column4: Fact Check: Amnesty International claim on 'shocking' Indigenous child incarceration rates checks out
column5: Amnesty International secretary general Salil Shetty claims the rate at which Western Australia jails Indigenous children is higher than the rate black children in the US are incarcerated.

column4: Fact check: Do higher food star ratings always mean a healthier choice?
column5: The Federal Government health star rating system for food and drink products, "the more stars, the healthier", is not as straighforward as it sounds.

column4: Fact check: Does a formal no case sink a constitutional referendum?
column5: Indigenous academic Marcia Langton claims constitutional recognition of Indigenous people will fail if conservatives lead a 'no case' against a proposed referendum.

column4: Fact check: Does infrasound from wind farms make people sick?
column5: Liberal Democrats senator David Leyonhjelm claims the low frequency sound of wind farms "cause adverse health impacts".

column4: Fact check: Would paying people smugglers to turn back boats be illegal?
column5: Greens leader Richard Di Natale says if the Abbott Government paid people smugglers to turn boats back to Indonesia it would have been a breach of domestic and international law.

column4: Fact Check: Are millions of taxpayer dollars being wasted on poorly performing IVF clinics?
column5: A leading IVF expert claims secrecy around IVF clinic success rates is wasting millions of dollars worth of Medicare rebates, as poorly performing clinics take more cycles to have a baby.

column4: Fact check: Do nine in 10 Australians spend more than 90 minutes a day commuting?
column5: Opposition Leader Bill Shorten claims nine out of 10 Australians spend more than 90 minutes a day commuting to work.

column4: Fact check: Does Australia spend more on offshore processing than the UN spends on refugee programs in South East Asia?
column5: Director of the Human Rights Law Centre Daniel Webb claims Australia is currently spending more than five times the United Nations refugee agency's entire budget for all of South East Asia on offshore processing of asylum seekers.

column4: Fact or fiction: A mother and father is better than same-sex parents
column5: An argument often used by religious groups against legalising same-sex marriage is that it will have a negative impact on children's wellbeing.

column4: Fact check: Are staff working in detention centres protected by whistleblower laws if they speak out?
column5: Labor's Immigration spokesman Richard Marles claims whistleblower protection, which applies across the public service, also applies to workers at the Manus and Nauru detention centres.

column4: Fact check: Do Australians pay less GST than people in other OECD nations?
column5: New South Wales Premier Mike Baird claims the average rate of GST across OECD nations is around 20 per cent, and Australia's GST is "right down the bottom"

column4: Fact check: Does the China Free Trade Agreement threaten Australian jobs?
column5: Unions claim the free trade agreement between Australia and China "allows Chinese companies to bring in their own workforce for projects over $150 million and removes the requirement that jobs be offered to local workers first".

column4: Fact check: Is Australia the sunniest continent on Earth?
column5: The ALP has called for a massive increase in renewable energy by 2030, with Opposition Leader Bill Shorten claiming Australia has more solar coverage than any other continent.

column4: Fact check: Is the proposed Shenhua Watermark coal mine located in the middle of Australia's best agricultural land?
column5: Agriculture Minister Barnaby Joyce says the Shenhua Watermark coal mine on the Liverpool Plains in northern New South Wales will be located in the middle of Australia's best agricultural land.

column4: Fact Check: Have electricity prices dropped $550 since the carbon tax was abolished?
column5: Treasurer Joe Hockey claims that Treasury documents show "electricity prices have come down $550 per household as a result of us abolishing the carbon tax".

column4: Fact check: Does Australia have one of the 'highest loss of species anywhere in the world'?
column5: Greens leader Richard Di Natale says it is important that endangered species be considered by the Federal Courts when approving coal mining projects, claiming Australia has "one of the highest loss of species anywhere in the world".

column4: Fact check: Why Tony Abbott's claims on emissions targets get mixed verdicts
column5: Prime Minister Tony Abbott claims Australia’s per capita emissions target for 2030 are “the best in the developed world”.

column4: Fact check: Is there 'no or very little' link between alcohol advertising and underage drinking?
column5: Amid concerns that children are exposed to thousands of alcohol advertisements during sport broadcasts, the Brewers Association claims there is no link or very little link between alcohol advertising and alcohol misuse, including underage drinking.

column4: Fact check: Is it a crime to attack a royal commissioner?
column5: Prime Minister Tony Abbott has defended Dyson Heydon's integrity and warned Labor MPs that it is a criminal offence to criticise a royal commissioner.

column4: Fact check: Is it illegal for Australia to bomb Islamic State in Syria?
column5: Independent federal MP Andrew Wilkie claims "it is illegal for Australia to bomb in Syria" because governments can't bomb a sovereign state which poses no threat to other countries.

column4: Fact check: Do big companies run by a Peter, a Michael, a David or an Andrew outnumber those run by women four to one?
column5: Sex Discrimination Commissioner Elizabeth Broderick said: "There are fewer big Australian companies that are run by women than by men named Peter."

column4: Fact check: Will Australia's refugee intake in 2015-16 be the highest since WWII?
column5: The Government has responded to the unfolding humanitarian crisis in the Middle East by announcing Australia will take an additional 12,000 refugees fleeing Syria and Iraq in 2015-16, which Foreign Minister Julie Bishop claims amounts to the single largest refugee intake since World War II.

column4: Fact check: Do many more people die by suicide than in road accidents?
column5: Lifeline Australia chairman John Brogden claims Australia's road toll has decreased significantly to less than half the number of deaths by suicide.

column4: Fact check: Do eight out of 10 taxpayers pay for Australia's social services bill?
column5: Treasurer Scott Morrison claims Australia has a spending problem, not a revenue problem.

column4: Fact check: How many students leave higher education with STEM qualifications?
column5: Opposition Leader Bill Shorten claims 16 per cent of Australian students graduate with STEM qualifications, a figure that is well below the completion rate for students in countries such as Singapore and China.

column4: Fact check: Does Uber need the law to change?
column5: The CEO of the Victorian Taxi Association, David Samuel, claims the arrival of Uber has left the established taxi industry the victim of an uneven playing field, with Uber not having to bear the costs that the rest of the industry faces.

column4: Fact Check: Was the cost of cutting emissions 100 times greater under Labor?
column5: Environment Minister Greg Hunt claims the Coalition's emissions reduction fund is around 1 per cent of the cost of reducing carbon under the former Labor government's carbon pricing scheme.

column4: Fact check: If diabetes were a country how big would it be?
column5: Federal Assistant Minister for Health Ken Wyatt claims diabetes is a growing global issue. Mr Wyatt said "if diabetes was a country it would be the fifth largest country in the world".

column4: Fact check: Christopher Pyne's claims on private schools and religion get mixed verdicts
column5: Minister for Industry, Innovation and Science, Christopher Pyne claims Australia has the highest proportion of non-government schools in the OECD, and almost all of them are religious.

column4: Fact check: Is Nauru virtually a failed state?
column5: Independent federal MP Andrew Wilkie claims the "Republic of Nauru is virtually a failed state".

column4: Fact check: Comparing Labor and the Coalition's records on foreign aid
column5: Opposition foreign affairs spokeswoman Tanya Plibersek announced Labor would restore $40 million to Australia's aid budget if re-elected and denies Labor also cut the aid budget when in government.

column4: Fact check: Are young Indigenous men more likely to end up in jail than university?
column5: Promising to set targets to close the gap between Indigenous and non-Indigenous people in the justice system, Opposition Leader Bill Shorten claims a young Aboriginal man of 18 is more likely to end up in jail than university.

column4: Fact check: Was superannuation designed to get people off the pension?
column5: Assistant Treasurer Kelly O'Dwyer claims Australia's superannuation system "was set up to be an alternative to the aged pension so that people didn't have to rely upon the aged pension or even the part pension".

column4: Fact check: Comparing Australia's income tax take with other OECD countries
column5: Treasurer Scott Morrison claims Australia relies more on income tax (personal and company) than any other country in the OECD except Denmark.

column4: Fact check: How do Australia's carbon emissions targets compare?
column5: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull claims the Government's emissions reduction target of 26 to 28 per cent of 2005 levels by 2030 are comparable to other "similarly situated" countries.

column4: Fact check: Do the Nationals represent Australia's poorest electorates?
column5: Deputy Nationals Leader Barnaby Joyce claims his party's constituents are Australia's poorest.

column4: Fact check: Does Australia export cleaner coal than many other countries?
column5: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull claims Australia's coal is "by and large" cleaner than coal from other countries.

column4: Fact check: Is Australia's emissions reduction target second only to Brazil's?
column5: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull claims Australia's emissions reduction target of 26 to 28 per cent of 2005 levels by 2030 is "second only to the emission cuts offered by Brazil" when measured on a per capita basis.

column4: Fact check: Is Australia's military contribution to the fight against Islamic State the second largest?
column5: Foreign Minister Julie Bishop claims Australia's contribution to the training mission in Iraq of 380 personnel is the second largest after the US, but there is more in the theatre than just training personnel.

column4: Fact Check: Are smart drum lines just a PR exercise?
column5: Humane Society International's Michael Kennedy, claims  a test of smart drums to protect swimmers from sharks in NSW is a PR exercise that will threaten other wildlife rather than make the beach safer.

column4: Fact check: Can a poker machine manufacturer use the TPP to challenge changes to gambling laws?
column5: Independent Senator Nick Xenophon claims the proposed Trans-Pacific Partnership trade agreement could allow overseas poker machine manufacturers to successfully sue the Government for passing anti-gambling laws.

column4: Fact check: Do the world's 62 richest people hold the same wealth as the poorest 50 per cent?
column5: Oxfam Australia CEO Helen Szoke claims the inequality gap between the rich and poor is widening faster than previously thought.

column4: Fact check: Are 2.5 million Australians in poverty and are one quarter of them children?
column5: Labor Opposition Leader Bill Shorten claims millions of Australians, more than 600,000 of them kids, are living below the poverty line. But what do the numbers show?

column4: Fact check: Are 30,000 women and 100,000 men sleeping rough on the streets of Australia?
column5: Former army chief and Australian of the Year David Morrison claims there are more Australians sleeping rough than there are soldiers in the Regular Army.

column4: Fact check: Were 301,000 jobs created in 2015?
column5: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull claims the Coalition Government has created more than 300,000 new jobs in a single year.

column4: Fact Check: Has the number of children in detention dropped from 2,000 to about 75 under the Coalition?
column5: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull claims that, since the Coalition came to power three years ago, more than 95 per cent of kids have been removed from immigration detention.

column4: Fact Check: Is Labor's schools policy fully funded?
column5: Shadow Treasurer Chris Bowen claims that Labor's decade-long schools policy, "your child, our future", is fully funded through future budget savings.

column4: Fact check: Are Indigenous children 10 times more likely than non-Indigenous children to be living out of home?
column5: Greens Senator Sarah Hanson-Young claims that, compared to non-Indigenous children, Indigenous kids are far more likely to be living in formal out-of-home care.

column4: Fact check: Do most negative gearers earn a modest income?
column5: Treasurer Scott Morrison claims Australians on modest incomes make up the "vast majority" of negative gearers — with two-thirds earning a taxable income of $80,000 or less, and a similar proportion owning just one property.

column4: Fact check: Did defence spending under Labor drop to its lowest level since 1938?
column5: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull claims the previous Labor government let defence spending, measured as a share of GDP, fall to pre-World War II levels.

column4: Fact check: What do the proposed Senate voting changes mean for above the line voting?
column5: Liberal Democratic Senator David Leyonhjelm claims the Government's proposed changes to Senate voting — to abolish group voting tickets and introduce optional preferential voting above the line — will make it near impossible for small parties to win a seat.

column4: Fact check: Do world class cities lack lockout laws?
column5: Campaigners say Sydney is out of step with comparable international cities, which they claim do not have lockout laws.

column4: Fact check: Why Michaelia Cash's claims on 457 visas get mixed verdicts
column5: Employment Minister Michaelia Cash says the number of migrant workers on 457 visas doubled under Labor then fell under the Coalition, accounting for less than one per cent of Australia's workforce in 2016. Is she correct?

column4: Fact check: Did the Greens win the seat of Melbourne in 2013 in their own right without having to rely on Liberal preferences?
column5: Greens MP Adam Bandt has accused Labor of "begging" the Liberals for voter preferences in the leadup to the 2016 election, claiming he retained his Melbourne seat in 2013 under his own steam, without Liberal preference flows.

column4: Fact check: Is Labor's increased tobacco excise a 'workers tax'?
column5: Former prime minister Tony Abbott claimed that if Labor wins the 2016 election they will bring in five new taxes, including "a tax on every worker having a smoko".

column4: Fact check: Did the 2015-16 Women's Big Bash League attract more viewers than the men's A-League?
column5: The inaugural Women's Big Bash League cricket competition scored a bigger TV audience than the men's A-League soccer season, the vice-captain of the Australian women's cricket team claims.

column4: Fact check: Have firearm homicides and suicides dropped since Port Arthur as a result of John Howard's reforms?
column5: Nearly twenty years after the Port Arthur massacre, John Howard, the prime minister who overhauled gun laws, claims they led to significant falls in gun-related homicides and a 74 per cent fall in gun-related suicide rates.

column4: Fact check: Did some crossbench Senators get more votes than Government ministers in 2013?
column5: In response to claims that independent and minor-party senators gained more personal votes than Government ministers in 2013, Fact Check asks whether below-the-line votes can be used as a measure of "personal" support.

column4: Fact check: Has the Coalition taken billions of dollars from hospitals and not put it back?
column5: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews claims hospitals have been shortchanged by the federal Coalition Government's new three-year funding deal, which he says does not return billions of dollars taken from the states and territories by the 2014 budget.

column4: Fact check: Did industrial disputes fall under the ABCC and rise after it was abolished?
column5: Employment Minister Michaelia Cash says industrial action in the construction sector fell after the Howard Government introduced a new building regulator, the Australian Building and Construction Commission and doubled after Labor abolished it.

column4: Fact check: Would building workers have less rights than ice dealers under ABCC laws?
column5: The CFMEU claims that if the Coalition re-establishes the Australian Building and Construction Commission, a worker will have "less rights than an ice dealer".

column4: Fact check: Did the budget take from working mums and give tax cuts to millionaires?
column5: Labor Opposition Leader Bill Shorten claims the 2016 federal budget will boost the take-home pay of millionaires while cutting payments for working mums, arguing that a mother earning $65,000 with two kids at high school would lose more than $4,500 in government payments.

column4: Fact check: Do two-thirds of negative gearers earn under $80,000?
column5: Assistant Treasurer Kelly O'Dwyer argues Labor's negative gearing policy would disadvantage average earners, claiming two-thirds of negative gearers have incomes of $80,000.

column4: Fact check: Did the Government triple the deficit and is debt $100b higher?
column5: Labor Opposition Senate Leader Penny Wong claims the Government has tripled the budget deficit in two years, and increased net debt by $100 billion since coming to office.

column4: Fact check: Is the Government not yet in caretaker mode?
column5: In response to accusations the Government was holding a defence industry roundtable during an election campaign, Industry Minister Christopher Pyne claimed that caretaker mode had not yet started.

column4: Fact check: Are the Government's super changes 'not at all' retrospective?
column5: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull claims changes to the tax treatment of superannuation for those who have high account balances or who plan to make large after-tax contributions in the future, are not retrospective.

column4: Fact check: Has the Government cut billions out of public hospitals?
column5: Two weeks into the 2016 election, Labor Opposition health spokeswoman Catherine King claims the Government has cut billions from public hospital funding.

column4: Fact check: Have bulk billing rates increased under the Coalition?
column5: Minister for Resources, Energy and Northern Australia Josh Frydenberg claims bulk billing rates have increased since the Coalition came to power, from an average of 79 per cent of services to 85 per cent.

column4: Fact check: Can ASIC do the same job as a financial industry royal commission?
column5: Labor promises to hold a royal commision into "misconduct in the banking and financial services industry". But Treasurer Scott Morrison claims there is nothing that ASIC can't do that a royal commission can do.

column4: Fact check: Is government spending today higher than it was in the GFC?
column5: Labor frontbencher Anthony Albanese claims spending is higher as a proportion of GDP in 2016 than it was during the global financial crisis.

column4: Fact check: Are there 'over a million 457s' in Australia?
column5: Independent Senator Jacqui Lambie claims 457 visas are partly responsible for a lack of employment opportunities in Australia, with more than a million such visas issued.

column4: Fact check: Do carbon emissions always rise under the Coalition?
column5: On its Facebook page, NSW Labor claims emissions always go up under the Liberals.

column4: Fact check: Would a vote among under 30s possibly deliver a Greens PM?
column5: Greens Leader Richard Di Natale claims identity politics is breaking down and that a vote among people under the age of 30 could deliver a Greens prime minister.

column4: Fact check: Do the Greens want Sydney to be without an airport?
column5: Labor spokesman for infrastructure and transport Anthony Albanese claims the Greens would close Kingsford Smith Airport and oppose Badgerys Creek airport, leaving Sydney with no airport at all.

column4: Fact check: Was Labor responsible for 'a record deficit'?
column5: Finance Minister Mathias Cormann claims Labor inherited a $20 billion surplus when it came into office in 2007 and then turned it into a record deficit.

column4: Fact check: Is wages growth now the lowest since records began?
column5: Labor's 10-year plan for the economy, released a month before the election, claims wages growth in 2016 is the lowest it has been since records began.

column4: Fact check: Has Australia's internet speed dropped from 30th to 60th in the world under the Coalition?
column5: Opposition communications spokesman Jason Clare claims Australia's global rank for internet speeds has fallen significantly under the Coalition.

column4: Fact check: Is Labor's economic plan the most comprehensive in living memory?
column5: Shadow treasurer Chris Bowen claimed Labor's 10-year plan for Australia's economy was the most comprehensive economic plan an opposition had released in living memory.

column4: Fact check: Why Peter Dutton's claims on the Coalition's record on refugees get mixed verdicts
column5: Immigration and Border Protection Minister Peter Dutton claims that he moved every child out of detention, brought record numbers of refugees in by plane and that nobody drowned at sea under Operation Sovereign Borders.

column4: Fact check: Did Labor previously make the same arguments as the Government on company tax?
column5: Labor says the Government's proposed program of business tax cuts is a massive cut to multinationals. But Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull claims Labor's support for corporate tax cuts in the past relied on the very same arguments that his government is now making.

column4: Fact check: Has the Government cut $22 billion from schools?
column5: Labor's education spokeswoman Tanya Plibersek says $22 billion worth of cuts to school funding over the next 10 years means the cuts would affect schools in the country and the city, including those in battling postcodes.

column4: Fact check: Did the Liberal Party lose a million votes last election?
column5: Senator for South Australia Cory Bernardi sought to justify his defection from the Liberal Party by claiming the party's support at the last election had dropped by 1 million votes.

column4: Fact check: Did Malcolm Turnbull announce a tax cut for millionaires and a tax hike for workers in the budget?
column5: Opposition leader Bill Shorten claims Malcolm Turnbull has announced a tax cut for millionaires and multinationals and tax hike for everyone else.
